subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|p}} – cloth on a loom, with threads crossing. Used phonetically.

subSections.title: Readings
Compounds
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|おれ}}

From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=おれ|-}}.  Found in use mostly from ancient times until roughly the {{w|Heian period}},<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref> used to refer in the [[second person]] to social [[inferior]]s or to [[insult]].<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref>

The [[second person]] sense of {{m|en|you}} appears to be obsolete in modern Japanese.

Not to be confused with the modern term {{m|ja|俺|tr=ore}} with the [[first person]] sense of {{m|en|I}}, {{m|en|me}}.  See {{m|ja|俺}} for that sense.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: Often used to [[insult]].  Compare modern {{cog|ja|お前|tr=omae}}, {{cog|en|you}} {{m|en|son of a bitch}}.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
Usage notes
subSections.text: No longer in use in modern Japanese outside of contexts where the speaker is deliberately invoking archaic usage.  Compare use of {{cog|en|thou}}.
